metadata.case_name: Ahmedabad Manufacturing Calico Printing Co. Ltd. & Ors. v. State of Gujarat & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Writ Petitions Nos. 12 and 17 to 21 of 1967, and 239, 240, 244 and 246 to 249 of 1966

facts.text: Twelve Writ Petitions by diverse textile mills and other factories of Ahmedabad challenging the imposition of the Education Cess pursuant to the Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962.

Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962 became law on October 9, 1962, to provide for the creation of a fund to promote education in the State of Gujarat. Applies to City of Ahmedabad under Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, 1949.

Education cess levied as: (a) surcharge on lands assessed to land revenue (except village sites), (b) tax on lands and buildings in urban areas. Surcharge under s.5 at 20 paise per rupee of land revenue on non-agricultural lands within village sites; s.7 surcharge on non-agricultural assessment; s.12 tax at 3% (later 4.5%) of annual letting value for trade/industry.
Annual letting value determined per assessment book under Corporation Act, using flat rate of Rs. 6-10as. per 100 sq. ft. processing, Rs. 5-4as. non-processing for textile mills.

In Writ Petitions Nos. 133 etc. of 1966, decided February 21, 1967 by Mitter J., floor area method and inclusion of plant/machinery in annual letting value held bad, discriminatory, and beyond legislative power.

Properties in Ahmedabad in three zones: inner zone (no land revenue, exempt under s.128 Bombay Land Revenue Code); middle zone (originally agricultural, diverted to non-agri, bear non-agri assessment + municipal tax); outer zone (pure agricultural, land revenue only). Textile mills in middle zone.
State of Gujarat concedes no current annual letting value available post striking down of assessment book, and no power to include plant/machinery.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.12 of Cess Act fails due to striking down of assessment book and inclusion of plant/machinery.
Whether discrimination under Art.14 due to middle zone paying both surcharge and tax, unlike other zones.
Whether Cess Act offends natural justice by not providing own assessment procedure, objections, appeals.

petitioner_arguments.text: Preparation of assessment book struck down, so annual letting value not available; s.12 inoperative, Cess Act falls as a whole.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962 s.12; Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Discrimination: middle zone properties pay both surcharge (s.7) and tax (s.12), while inner zone pays only tax, outer only surcharge.
No procedure in Cess Act for valuation, objections, representations, appeals; offends natural justice.

respondent_arguments.text: Concedes assessment book struck down, no current annual letting value or inclusion of plant/machinery.

court_reasoning.text: S.12 does not fail; it applies to annual letting value as determined under Corporation Act; remains valid pending new assessment book.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section remains on statute book to be worked into future assessment book.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination; zones result from different laws (Bombay Land Revenue Code ss.126-128); cess adjusts rates equitably based on situation/advantages; double levy not offensive to Art.14 without proof of heavier burden; flat rate issue already corrected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Method of calculation different in zones; rates may be adjusted equitably.

court_reasoning.text: Cess is addition to existing taxes (percentage thereof); no need for separate assessment/objections/appeals as those available under base Acts; common for cesses; constitutional.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arithmetical calculation based on scrutinized assessments under other Acts.

holdings.text: S.12 of Cess Act valid despite struck-down assessment book.
No violation of Art.14; no discrimination between zones.
Cess Act provides adequate procedure via base Acts; no violation of natural justice.

precedents_cited.relevance: Struck down assessment book method for textile factories; binding on flat rate and plant/machinery inclusion.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Education Cess Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of education cess as surcharge or tax on lands/buildings; rates and basis upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for annual letting value; Corporation powers co-terminous with State.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Village sites, exemptions from land revenue; basis for zones.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; equality challenged and rejected.

outcome.summary: Court declines to issue writ; upholds validity of Cess Act provisions against challenges; assessment book to be revised per prior judgment.

key_quotes.text: "The section remains on the statute book to be worked into such assessment book as may hereafter emerge."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds s.12 valid pending new assessment.

key_quotes.text: "A double imposition by itself is not offensive to Art. 14 of the Constitution unless it can be shown that the double tax...falls more heavily than the single tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The cess is nothing more than an addition to existing taxes. As it is a percentage of another tax, the determination of the cess is not by an independent assessment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
